STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
April 30, 2025
Linda Sue Needham
Monroe County DHHS
903 S Telegraph Rd,
Monroe, MI, 48161-5538
Re: License #: CP580201306
Dear Ms. Needham:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
3/17/2025. An Exit conference was held with your agency on 3/31/2025. Due to the
violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP580201306
Licensee Group Organization: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Designee: Demetrius LuJuan Starling
Chief Administrator: Linda SUE Needham
Name of Agency: Monroe County DHHS
Agency Address: 903 S TELEGRAPH RD
MONROE, MI 48161-5538
Agency Telephone #: 3132437203
Original Issuance Date: 07/01/1989
Service Types: Certify foster homes for license, Evaluate
Applicants for adoption, Place children for
adoption, Place children in foster home,
Supervise Independent Living
1

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION
A. Consultant
Date(s) of On-site Inspection: 3/11/25, 3/12/14
Total No. Of No. of
Records Records
Reviewed
Current licensed foster homes 30 5
Homes pending licensure 6 4
Foster homes closed since the last inspection 8 3
Foster homes borrowed since the last inspection 4 3
Special Investigations in foster homes since last inspection 7 5
Incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect
in foster care since last inspection 0 0
Incidents of substantiated corporal punishment in foster care
since last inspection 0 0
Children receiving direct foster care case management
(placement in foster homes, parental home,
relative homes, CCI, hospital, etc.) 46 6
Children discharged from care during this period 18 4
Youth in independent living placement 3 3
Youth discharged from an independent living placement
since the last inspection 1 1
Applicants approved for adoption since the last inspection N/A N/A
Applicants denied for adoption since the last inspection N/A N/A

Open child adoption cases N/A N/A

More than a year 15 6

2

B. Analyst
Total No. No. Visited
Licensed foster homes 31 3
Unlicensed relative homes 8 3
Number of persons interviewed:
Foster Parents 3
Foster Children 10
Relatives 3
Others (identify person interviewed by role) 0
III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12312 Foster parent training.
(4) At least 1 adult member of the household must have
training in and maintain a current certification in first aid
and cardiopulmonary resuscitation from the American
Heart Association or the American Red Cross, or other
institution approved by the department.
One of five open foster home records reviewed did not show documentation of a
current CPR and first aid certification for the foster parent, as required by the rule.
CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(2) The annual reevaluation must include a determination
and assessment of all the following:
(b) Family functioning and interrelationships as
determined by observation of, and interviews with, each
member of the household and each social service worker
who has had children placed in the home during the last
licensing period.
Two of five open foster home records reviewed did not show a summary of all
interviews of household members, as required by the rule.
2

CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and make a
licensing recommendation to the department at least 15
calendar days before the expiration date of the foster
home license.
One of five open foster home records reviewed showed the agency's
recommendation to the department did not occur at least 15 days prior to the foster
home's 5/24/2024 license expiration date.
Repeat Violation:
2024 Renewal, CAP approved 4/18/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the
child in a foster home, then both the following must be
documented before a change in placement:
(a) A summary of the services provided during care up to
the time of the change in placement and the needs that
remain to be met.
One of four closed foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of a
summary of services provided during the period, as required by the rule.
Repeat Violation Established:
2024 Renewal, CAP approved 4/18/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the
child in a foster home, then both the following must be
documented before a change in placement:
(b) Provision for any continuing services.
One of four closed foster child records reviewed did not show documentation as to
whether there was provision for any continuing services, as required by the rule.
Repeat Violation Established:
2024 Renewal, CAP approved 4/18/2024.
3

CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all the following in the
child's record before a change of placement occurs:
(b) If the child is not returned to the parent, then the
reason why return is not possible.
One of six open foster child records reviewed, where the child was replaced several
times, did not show documentation related to why return to the parent was not
possible.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all the following in the
child's record before a change of placement occurs:
(e) Replacement preparation of all relevant parties,
including the child or infant, which includes an
explanation as to why the change is necessary.
In two of six open foster child records reviewed, where the child was returned home
on one case, and replaced several times on the other case, the record did not show
documentation of the child's and all relevant parties’ preparation for the change.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,
include all the following:
(d) Current immunizations for each child as required by
section 5111 of the public health code, 1978 PA 368,
MCL 333.5111. All the following apply:
(iii) If documentation of immunization or a copy of the
waiver is unavailable, then immunizations must begin
within 30 calendar days of placement.
Two of six open foster child records reviewed show one or more of the respective
child's immunizations had expired, and immunizations for such had not begun as
required by rule.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
4

(2) An agency shall maintain a file documentation from
the medical or dental provider of all medical and dental
care received by a foster child.
Four of six open foster child records reviewed did not show that the child's medical
and/or dental examination was documented from the medical or dental provider as
required by the rule. A 360 connect verification, explanation of benefits form or
other non-medical/dental documentation showed the child's examination.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for
each child and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and
at least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
In one of six open foster child records reviewed the record showed two late service
plans, which were 10 and 12 days late respectively.
Repeat Violation Established:
2024 Renewal, CAP approved 4/18/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(5) An agency shall involve the child's parent or parents
and the foster parents in the development of service
plans to enable the parent or parents and foster parents
to understand the plan for the child and the parents' and
the foster parent's role in assisting the agency in carrying
out the plan. An agency shall give a copy to and review
the parent-agency treatment plan with the parent or
parents and foster parents. The agency must inform the
parent or parents and foster parent that the information
in the parent-agency treatment plan and any other
information about the child and the child's family is
confidential.
Three of six open foster child records reviewed did not show timely documentation
of either the caregiver’s and or the birth parent’s signature on one or more service
plans, as required by the rule.
Repeat Violation Established:
2024 Renewal, cited under FOM 722-8D, CAP approved 4/18/2024.
2023 Interim, cited under FOM 722-8D, CAP approved 6/16/2023.
5

CPA Rule 400.12419 Initial service plans.
(1) The initial service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(a), must include all the following
information:
(c) Assessment of the placement selection criteria as
required under R 400.12404(4).
One of six open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of the
child's placement selection criteria in the child’s initial service plan, as required by
the rule.
Repeat Violation Established:
2024 Renewal, CAP approved 4/18/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12505 Supervision.
(2) An agency shall provide the following minimum
supervision:
(a) Face-to-face contact between the social service
worker and the youth in independent living at least once
each month at a youth's place of residence.
In one of three independent living youth records reviewed the record did not show
documentation of a June 2024 visit with the youth in the youths' placement.
CPA Rule 400.12507 Medical, dental and mental health care.
(1) An agency shall ensure that a youth in independent
living receives any needed medical, dental, and mental
health care as required in R 400.12413. Medical, dental,
and mental health care provided must be documented in
the youth's record.
In two of three open independent living youth records reviewed the respective
record showed one youth's 5/14/2024 medical exam; and the other youth’s
3/22/2024 dental exam were not on documentation from the service provider. The
latter record also did not show documentation of the annual medical exam for the
youth, which was due by 8/6/2024.
6

CPA Rule 400.12509 Independent living record.
(3) The case record must contain all the following
information and documentation, which must be recorded
within 30 calendar days after placement in independent
living and updated at least once every 90 calendar days:
(o) Service plans as required in R 400.12419 and R
400.12420. If the youth has biological children, the
service plan must address the living arrangement for the
child or children, visitation/parenting time with the youth's
biological children or a clear explanation why this is not
possible or appropriate.
One of three open independent living youth records reviewed did not show all
required staff or the youth’s signature on three service plans, as required by the
rule.
CPA Rule 400.12511 Termination.
(2) An agency shall ensure and document that each
youth who ends independent living is provided with all
the following:
(b) A birth certificate.
One of one closed independent living youth records reviewed did not show
documentation that the youth was provided with a copy of a birth certificate, as
required by the rule.
CPA Rule 400.12511 Termination.
(2) An agency shall ensure and document that each
youth who ends independent living is provided with all
the following:
(a) Basic information about health, housing, counseling
and mental health services, and emergency resources.
One of one closed independent living youth records reviewed did not show that
basic information about health, housing, counseling and mental health, and
emergency service information was provided to the youth, as required by the rule.
7

CPA Rule 400.12511 Termination.
(2) An agency shall ensure and document that each
youth who ends independent living is provided with all
the following:
(d) The youth's funds and personal property.
One of one closed independent living youth records reviewed did not show
documentation as to whether the youth was provided with all of the youth’s funds
and personal property, as required by the rule.
CPA Rule 400.12511 Termination.
(2) An agency shall ensure and document that each
youth who ends independent living is provided with all
the following:
(c) A social security card.
One of one closed independent living youth records reviewed did not show
documentation that the youth was provided with a copy of a social security card, as
required by the rule.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all
the following information:
(e) Conclusions regarding licensing rules compliance or
noncompliance based on the findings of fact.
One of five special evaluations reviewed showed the licensing action was not
consistent with facts contained in the special evaluation, as evidence showed a rule
noncompliance.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was provided with technical assistance in the following areas:
R400.12324(2)(b) Reevaluation:
The agency is appraised it shall consistently and clearly show documentation of
each foster parent's strengths and weaknesses as assessed by worker and as
reported by each foster parent.
8

V. CONSULTATION
The facility was provided with consultation in the following areas:
R400.12507 Medical, dental and mental health care.
The agency was re-advised consistently uploading the youth’s refusal medical form
may aid in showing compliance with the rule.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There was no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no substantiated incidents of corporal punishment during this licensing
period
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted one corrective plan during this licensing period. This
corrective action plan related to the agency’s 2024 renewal inspection completed
on 3/7/2024. During the 2024 inspection the agency received 10 rule violations, 6
are repeat citations this year. Of those 6 with the exception of one where the
number of cases cited decreased; the other noncompliance case numbers
remained the same. The agency plans to continue its efforts to address repeat
violations and to strive to establish compliance across the board. Further action
steps will need to be implemented to achieve compliance.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The chief administrator (CA)'s report indicated the agency has been diligently
working to provide support and services to parents to promote reunification.
Additionally, the team has been working to address areas of non-compliance from
last year’s inspection. The CA reported that the agency has discovered that when
staff have extremely stressful cases, documentation or due dates may get missed;
and it’s difficult to adjust for these stress-minded errors. The CA report further
indicated the agency has discovered when staff and management are both
involved in CAP development, there is more success with it; and tracking and
follow-up is also more successful.
The CA report indicated the agency plans to continue having monthly reviews of
policy and procedures with staff. Local processes, checklist use and following
procedures will also continue to be used, along with adjustments to CAPs when
warranted to bring about rule compliance.
The CA report indicated the agency’s strengths to be its continued ability to team
together on cases, and for families. Additionally, they will continue to use a
trauma lense approach in servicing all family members. An area for more focus or
growth was indicated as gaining more consistency with thorough documentation of
9

the work that they complete. The agency indicated it will continue its efforts to
achieve greater and ongoing rule compliance.
Financial Overview
Not applicable.
Staff Interviews
In addition to discussion with the chief administrator, the program manager and
the two supervisors, I interviewed one licensing worker and two foster care
workers. The managerial staff reported staff morale to be good, caseload counts
have been maintained, and they have been able to provide staff with the support
they appear to need. The direct care staff interviewed reported there is great
teamwork, great communication and managerial staff are available and
supportive. Additionally, they reported that employees’ mental health is valued,
and patience and compassion is shown to them in this area by management.
No direct agency area of growth was reported as needed, but continued
work/improvement in communication with the court; and CWLM were mentioned
as areas continue improvement is desired.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walk through the facility did not reveal any safety issues or areas of concern.
The agency has sufficient equipment for its staff and records are securely stored.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There was one Safety Alert during this reporting period.
Safety Alert: There was no operable smoke detector in the basement of the home.
Resolution: Agency staff went to the home on 02/13/2025 and installed the smoke
detector in the basement of the home. A photo was provided showing the
installation.
10

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
April 29, 2025
________________________________________
Lonia Perry Calloway Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
April 30, 2025
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
11
